commentBody: Thanks for the explanation of the triangle and circle shapes. I would not have figured out the extra layer (CHIPS and SALSA) on my own. At least I figured out the double dips before I finished the puzzle!
Phew. What a relief after a week where I went disastrously over my average on every other puzzle to finally have one where I came in way under.

Great Thursday puzzle.

Nice fill without esoteric trivia. Good difficulty and although similar themes have been done before, this was done well.

9/10

OCCAM‚ÄôS razor of Thursday crosswords:
Trying to finagle a meaning out of ‚ÄúSimulated mopeds bringing freight to the Capitol carets‚Äù is wrong. 
‚ÄúChips and salsa‚Äù is much simpler! And more fun.  

Don‚Äôt forget to add cilantro!
Very crunchy puzzle, great Thursday! (And no lookups either, woot!)
Both the Mini and today's puzzle were clever and fun. No look ups.

Since yesterday's installment was so popular, here's a new list of the anticipated nits from today's puzzle:

Theme:
--How do I write the rebus?
--It's not a rebus?
--Circles are bad enough; triangles, too?
--I'm supposed to go up and down and up and down?
--The triangles spell what?
--The circles spell what?
--I don't get it.

Clues and Answers:

Foreign languages:
EAU--I'm supposed to know French?
ALEPH--I'm supposed to know other alphabets?
MAIS OUI--More French?

Computers and phones:
MSN--What is this, 1990?
AGE--Ugh, online dating.
OTOH--Ugh, textspeak.
TBH--Ugh, more textspeak.
DMED--Ugh, social media.
LCD--A kealoa. Could be LED. Or even CRT.
WIFI--Nothing wrong with the clue. But how many tech words are there going to be?

Abbreviations and initialisms:
PLO, IED, LCD, TBH, OTOH, DMED, DJS, IPASGSU, STP, GSU, CSIS--How many flippin' letter salads are there going to be?
APT--Wait...that's not an abbreviation?!?!?!

Sportsball:
GSU--I'm supposed to know random abbreviations about college sports teams?
TIPINS--Come on, it's not even clear what sport that is.  Basketball? Golf? Both of them?
END--Football is too violent. I never watch it.

Also:
ATOMIC DOG--I'm supposed to know some song that barely made the charts over 40 years ago?
UVEA--Too obscure.
MEDEA--Wasn't she in those Tyler Perry movies?
MEDIA--Wasn't she in those Tyler Perry movies?
ESSIE--I'm supposed to know nail polish brands?
OCCAM--I'm supposed to know a 14th century dude?

Happy solving, folks!
The CHIPS and SALSA  part of the theme really rounded it out, I only wish there was a hint to that in the puzzle because I never would have noticed that on my own
Wow hard Thurs!

I picked up on the DOUBLE DIP trick at CAP PISTOL for ‚ÄúToy Shooter‚Äù. But why, I asked myself, is one dip represented by a triangle and the other a circle? I finished and was still puzzled. I stared and stared at the completed grid. Surely there is reason for the different shapes. MAIS OUI!  The triangles are CHIPS and the circles are SALSA. What a brilliant Easter egg. 

Thanks, Rick and Simeon. That was fun!

C‚Äômon, everyone knows that a circus performer would never juggle chainsaws on a tightrope! They‚Äôd be on a unicycle: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=amV8yoDISRM Nice to have a Thursday with some ‚Äúbite‚Äù.

Completely unrelated to crosswords, so feel free to skip this post. 

I wonder how many of you have heard of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy?

In layman's terms, it is known as broken heart syndrome. The name itself has interesting Japanese origins about hunting octopodes, but that is besides the point. For those who have not heard about it, it is when a spouse dies and the surviving spouse, seemingly in good health previously, dies shortly thereafter.

I posted in December when my grandmother passed away. My grandfather lives in a care home with dementia, but otherwise seemed to be doing well. My aunts finally cleaned out their condo last week and moved/sold everything. They told grandpa that it was done a few days ago. 2 days later, he developed liver failure. I just came back from the hospital; he has metastatic cancer to all of his internal organs.

Now, for the cancer to be this widespread, it MUST have been present for a long time even before my grandmother's funeral. That's the scientist in me talking. The timing is just an odd coincidence though. He was doing fine, grandma died, his affairs were settled, and then his body decided that "it's time". There is definitely more to our spirit that science does not yet fully understand. 

Ironically, I'm boarding a plane for NYC in a few hours (and part of our visit includes an NYT tour). So I'm glad that I got to see him one last time, because I'm pretty sure he won't be here when we get back.

Once I realized the double dip, it started getting way easier.  Still have some Greek lore to learn. 

If anyone wants some help with learning lore, the Podcast Myths and Legends is a good one.

I still know no French at all.  But this time I immediately skipped it, and after I'd taken my best guess at the crosses, I looked at it and said "Looks French to me.  Lotsa vowel, oui at the end looks like a word in French, so I guess I'm ok."

No biggie now.  Seismic eruptions then.

In all my years, I have never heard anyone say "simulcasted".
"Simulcast" is a portmanteau of "simultaneous" and "broadcast", and the commonly used past tense of "broadcast" is "broadcast".  Similarly, the past tense of "simulcast" is typically also "simulcast".
I can‚Äôt wait for Larry Moana to tell us how smart he was today!

Very fun! 

The comments today are also great fun. This is typical, of course, but sometimes a particular puzzle brings out even more (unintentional?) hilarity. Everyone who's upset - at a puzzle, no less - and everyone else who's strutting around, puffed up - again, about a puzzle... - and then there's always someone over to one side, hollering about random minutiae incorrectly yet with strong conviction, while the rest of us softly cluck and concentrate intently on our grubworms, hoping the offending bird will discover, unassisted, awareness, and pipe down before someone has to take it by the wing for a little walk around the yard and an explanation. ain't nobody here but us chickens! ü§£ Being one myself, i enjoy this community of other cluckers and the amusement it brings: a daily Fowl Ball ü§£.

i'll see myself out. Have a great day, all!

A small nit to pick:

Although most people interpret Occam's razor to mean "the simplest explanation is the most likely to be correct," it actually says that the explanation with the fewest assumptions is probably the best one.

And yes, the explanation with the fewest assumptions can also be the simplest one...but not necessarily.

Before the most important question ‚Äì How was the solve? ‚Äì an observation about this amazing grid-build, in which Rich and Simeon had to:
‚Ä¢	Find answers that with and without the double dipping were bona fide words.
‚Ä¢	Place them symmetrically, which required that theme answers consist of equal length pairs.
‚Ä¢	Have the triangle letters spell CHIPS, and the circle letters spell SALSA.
‚Ä¢	Ensure that the answers containing shapes are bona fide words.

Wow!  A huge bow to the grunt work behind this!

Now, the solve.  For me, riddles aplenty to crack ‚Äì Why shapes?  Why two types of them?  What is the reveal (after I purposely left it blank)? All on top of filling in the box.

When there are riddles aplenty, my brain hums with happiness. The trying, to my brain, is as sweet as the succeeding, and today, there was plenty of both.  

Rich (10 NYT puzzles) and Simeon (15), this was the first NYT collaboration for either of you, and it was stellar.  I felt like a kid in a candy shop.  More please, and thank you!

Interesting how many people want the past tense of "simulcast" to be "simulcast", rather than "simulcasted". Both Merriam-Webster and Collins acknowledge "simulcasted", which seems the natural usage to me.
As Steven Pinker pointed out, we tend to regularize irregular nouns and verbs when we use them in compounds or figuratively; so while the past tense of "cast" is "cast", the "-ed" tends to intrude when we reach for the past tense of "broadcast", to use an older example. The OED has examples of "broadcasted" going back to the early nineteenth century

Knowing the issue I was terribly worried for my dad when my mom died 3 years ago. They married young and were together for 50 years (mom died of cancer at 70, seven months short of their 50th anniversary), and while they may not have been the perfect couple (who is?), they were very close and their union simply worked: they complemented one another perfectly, and I could see how they enjoyed spending time together. Their marriage taught me how silly most stereotypes about gender, relations between women and men, and between spouses were.

So yeah. When mom died I was terrified my dad would deteriorate. He has some health issues of his own, so the threat seemed real. I tried to support him in any way I could, but he comes from hardy stock, the proud people of the Mazovian countryside, so emotionally he would just not open up to work out grief. Still, I started to spend as much time as I could with him, and also talking to him on the phone daily. I made sure he stayed active, and that he engaged with other people. It helped that he must have realized the risks himself. 

He turned 75 last year. He is very physically active, walking as much as 12 km daily. He writes books. He meets friends and family. He is a pillar of his local community (he was elected to the disctrict council last year). He takes his health seriously. He's doing great - but only because he apparently wanted to make the effort to become so.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

In the Jewish religion, we only name our kids for deceased relatives.  My son, who is our elder child, is named for both his paternal great-grandfathers.

When my grandmother who was the wife of my  son's namesake (i.e. first name) died, my son was only a toddler.  When we got to the cemetery, my wife saw my grandfather's grave,  next to where my grandmother was about to be buried, and she shivered.

Although the middle initial was different, it was my son's name, and close enough to really shake her.  I had to remind her that the middle initial was different, and it was therefore a different person altogether.

She still tells that story when naming after family comes up in conversation.

When my daughter was born, she was named after two of her great-grandmothers, but we altered the first name just a little, and that scene won't ever be duplicated.

@Domenic Many years ago, when I started commenting on puzzles on this and other websites, I relied on what I knew, or thought I knew, to formulate opinions that I presented much like you did. I soon realized that I didn't know as much as I thought I knew, and I didn't know how crossword clues and answers functioned. In a crossword, an answer is acceptable if it is in any way a possible answer to the clue. It doesn't have to be the most common one, or the one that would come to most people first. And often, it's very easy to verify whether the answer can fit the clue; after all, the same device you're using to write your nit can also tell you your answer. So, let's do that. About two seconds of effort produced a page listing these sites and a few others like them: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/simulcast https://www.collinsdictionary.com/us/conjugation/english/simulcast https://www.dictionary.com/browse/simulcast All of them say "simulcasted" is a past tense form of "simulcast". Also, consider that each puzzle has a constructor, at least one editor, and then several test solvers. It's inconceivable that at no point in the process did anyone bother to fact check this word. But don't worry. A solver called DW from NY already raised this question, and got, to this point, 61 recommendations. All that means is that there are 64 (including your recommender) people out there who don't know what I just told you above. TL; DR: Simulcasted is proper.
